{{Use British English|date=April 2012}} [[Image:Chwe Chenedl Geltaidd.png|thumb|280px|
The six ''Celtic nations'' within their modern borders are shown in yellow
]] The modern '''Celts''' ({{IPAc-en|k|ɛ|l|t|s|}}, see [[Names of the Celts#Pronunciation|pronunciation of ''Celt'']]) are a related group of [[ethnicity|ethnicities]] who share similar [[Celtic languages]], cultures and artistic histories, and who live in or descend from one of the [[Celtic nations|regions]] on the western extremities of [[Europe]] populated by the [[Celts]].{{cite web|url=https://www.livescience.com/44666-history-of-the-celts.html|title=History of the Celts|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/celtic|title=Celtic Meaning in the Cambridge English Dictionary|website=dictionary.cambridge.org}} A modern Celtic identity emerged in [[Western Europe]] following the identification of the native peoples of the Atlantic fringe as Celts by [[Edward Lhuyd]] in the 18th century. Lhuyd and others equated the Celts described by [[Greco-Roman]] writers with the pre-Roman peoples of [[France]], [[Great Britain]] and [[Ireland]]. They categorised the ancient Irish and British languages as [[Celtic languages]]. The descendants of these ancient languages are the [[Brittonic languages|Brittonic]] ([[Breton language|Breton]], [[Cornish language|Cornish]] and [[Welsh language|Welsh]] variants) and [[Goidelic languages|Gaelic]] ([[Irish language|Irish]], [[Manx language|Manx]] and [[Scottish Gaelic|Scottish]] variants) languages, and the people who speak them are considered modern Celts. The concept of modern Celtic identity evolved during the course of the 19th century into the [[Celtic Revival]]. By the late 19th century, it often took the form of [[ethnic nationalism]], particularly within the [[United Kingdom of Great Britain and Ireland]], where the [[Irish Home Rule Movement]] resulted in the secession of the [[Irish Free State]], in 1922. There were also significant [[Welsh nationalism|Welsh]], [[Scottish nationalism|Scottish]] and [[Breton nationalist]] movements, giving rise to the concept of [[Celtic nations]]. After [[World War II]], the focus of the Celtic movement shifted to [[linguistic revival]] and [[linguistic protectionism|protectionism]], e.g. with the foundation of the [[Celtic League (political organisation)|Celtic League]] in 1961, dedicated to preserving the surviving [[Celtic languages]].{{cite web|title=Celtic League – About us|url=http://www.celticleague.net/about-us/|website=Celticleague.net|accessdate=9 January 2018}} The Celtic revival also led to the emergence of [[Celtic music|musical]] and [[Celtic art#Celtic revival|artistic styles]] identified as Celtic. Music typically drew on folk traditions within the Celtic nations. Art drew on decorative styles associated with the ancient Celts and with early medieval [[Celtic Christianity]], along with folk-styles. Cultural events to promote "inter-Celtic" cultural exchange also emerged. In the late 20th century some authors criticised the idea of modern Celtic identity, usually by downplaying the value of the linguistic component in defining culture and cultural connection, sometimes also arguing that there never was a common Celtic culture, even in ancient times. These authors usually opposed language preservation efforts. Malcolm Chapman's 1992 book ''The Celts: The Construction of a Myth'' led to what the archaeologist, [[Barry Cunliffe]] has called a "politically correct disdain for the use of 'Celt'"Barry Cunliffe, ''The Ancient Celts'', Oxford University Press, 1997, p.276. ==Definitions== Traditionally, the essential defining criterion of Celticity is seen as ''peoples and countries that do, or once did, use Celtic languages'' and it is asserted that an index of connectedness to the [[Celtic languages]] has to be borne in mind before branching out into other cultural domains.{{cite book | last = Koch | first = John T. (editor) | title = Celtic Culture: a historical encyclopedia | publisher = ABC-Clio | year = 2005 | page = xx | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=f899xH_quaMC&pg=PA196 | id = | isbn = 978-1-85109-440-0 | accessdate =18 September 2009 }} Another approach to defining ''the Celts'' is the contemporary inclusive and associative definition used by [[Vincent Megaw|Vincent and Ruth Megaw]] (1996) and [[Raimund Karl]] (2010) that a Celt is someone who uses a Celtic language or produces or uses a distinctive Celtic cultural expression (such as art or music) or has been referred to as a Celt in historical materials or has identified themselves or been identified by others as a Celt or has a demonstrated descent from the Celts (such as family history or DNA ancestry).{{cite journal|last=Megaw|first=J. V. S. & M. R.|title=Ancient Celts and modern ethnicity|journal=Antiquity|year=1996|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Ancient+Celts+and+modern+ethnicity.-a018299489}}{{cite book|last=Karl|first=Raimund|title=Celtic from the West Chapter 2: The Celts from everywhere and nowhere: a re-evaluation of the origins of the Celts and the emergence of Celtic cultures|year=2010|publisher=Oxbow Books, Oxford, UK|isbn=978-1-84217-410-4|pages=39–64}} Since the [[Age of Enlightenment|Enlightenment]], the term ''Celtic'' has been applied to a wide variety of peoples and cultural traits present and past. Today, ''Celtic'' is often used to describe people of the [[Celtic nations]] (the [[Bretons]], the [[Cornish people|Cornish]], the [[Irish people|Irish]], the [[Manx people|Manx]], the [[Scottish people|Scots]] and the [[Welsh people|Welsh]]) and their respective cultures and languages.{{cite web|title=Who were the Celts? ... Rhagor|url=http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/rhagor/article/celts/|accessdate=5 February 2015|publisher=[[National Museum Cardiff|Amgueddfa Cymru – National Museum Wales]]|date=4 May 2007|work=Amgueddfa Cymru – National Museum Wales website|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150205060947/http://www.museumwales.ac.uk/rhagor/article/celts/|archivedate=5 February 2015|df=dmy-all}} Except for the Bretons (if discounting Norman & Channel Islander connections), all groups mentioned have been subject to strong [[Anglicisation]] since the [[Early Modern period]], and hence are also described as participating in an [[Anglo-Celtic]] macro-culture. By the same token, the Bretons have been subject to strong [[Frenchification]] since the [[Early Modern period]], and can similarly be described as participating in a Franco-Celtic macro-culture. Less common is the assumption of ''Celticity'' for European cultures deriving from [[Continental Celtic]] roots ([[Gauls]] or [[Celtiberians]]). These were either Romanised or Germanised much earlier, before the Early Middle Ages. Nevertheless, ''Celtic'' origins are many times implied for continental groups such as the [[Asturian people|Asturians]], [[Galician people|Galicians]], [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]], [[Swiss people|Swiss]], Northern [[Italians]], [[Belgians]]{{Cite book|last=Chadwick|first=Nora|title=The Celts|year=1970|publisher=Penguin Books|page=53}} or [[Austrians]]. The names of [[Belgium]] and the [[Aquitaine]] hark back to ''[[Gallia Belgica]]'' and ''[[Gallia Aquitania]]'', respectively, in turn named for the [[Belgae]] and the [[Aquitani]].{{Cite book|last=Wightman|first=Edith Mary|title=Gallia Belgica|year=1985|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=0-520-05297-8|pages=12, 26–29|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=aEyS54uSj88C }}{{Cite book|last=Laurent|first=Peter Edmund|title=An introduction to the study of ancient geography|year=1868|publisher=Oxford|pages=20, 21|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Q00ZAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA20 }} The Latin name of the [[Swiss Confederacy]], ''Confoederatio Helvetica'', harks back to the [[Helvetii]], the name of [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] to the [[Gallaeci]] and the [[Auvergne (province)|Auvergne]] of France to the [[Averni]]. ==Celtic revival and Romanticism== {{Further|Celtic Revival}} [[File:Celtic congress 1904.jpg|thumb|280px|Delegates at the Pan-Celtic Congress, Caernarfon, 1904. Back row: Maggie Jones (harpist of Arfon); Mrs Gruffydd Richards (chief harpist of Gwent), David Roberts (blind harpist of Mawddwy), [[Gwyneth Vaughan]]. Front row: Pedwr James, [[Émile Hamonic]], Léna Botrel, [[Théodore Botrel]], Professor Paul Barbier]] 'Celt' has been adopted as a label of self-identification by a variety of peoples at different times. 'Celticity' can refer to the inferred links between them. During the 19th century, French nationalists gave a privileged significance to their descent from the [[Gauls]]. The struggles of [[Vercingetorix]] were portrayed as a forerunner of the 19th-century struggles in defence of French nationalism, including the wars of both Napoleons ([[Napoleon I of France]] and [[Napoleon III of France]]). Basic French history textbooks emphasised the ways in which Gauls (''"Nos ancêtres les Gaulois..."'', 'our ancestors the Gauls') could be seen as an example of cultural assimilation.Weber, Eugen (1991) "Gauls versus Franks: conflict and nationalism", in ''Nationhood and Nationalism in France'', edited by Robert Tombs. London: HarperCollins Academic; Dietler, Michael (1994) "'Our ancestors the Gauls': archaeology, ethnic nationalism, and the manipulation of Celtic identity in modern Europe", ''American Anthropologist'' 96:584–605. In the late Middle Ages, some French writers believed (incorrectly) that their language was primarily Celtic, rather than Latin.Posner, Rebecca.''Romance Languages''. Page 3. A similar use of ''Celticity'' for 19th-century nationalism was made in [[Switzerland]], when the Swiss were seen to originate in the Celtic tribe of the [[Helvetii]], a link still found in the official Latin name of Switzerland, ''Confœderatio Helvetica'', the source of the nation code CH and the name used on postage stamps (Helvetia). Before the advance of [[Indo-European studies]], [[philology|philologists]] established that there was a relationship between the [[Goidelic]] and [[Brythonic languages]], as well as a relationship between these languages and the extinct Celtic languages such as [[Gaulish]], spoken in classical times. The terms Goidelic and Brythonic were first used to describe the two [[Celtic languages|Celtic language families]] by [[Edward Lhuyd]] in his 1707 study and, according to the [[National Museum Cardiff|National Museum Wales]], during that century "people who spoke Celtic languages were seen as Celts." At the same time, there was also a tendency to play up alternative heritages in the [[British Isles]] at certain times. For example, in the Isle of Man, in the [[Victorian era]], the ''[[Viking]]'' heritage was emphasised, and in Scotland, both Norse and [[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]] heritage was emphasised. A [[Romanticism|romantic]] image of the Celt as [[noble savage]] was cultivated by the early [[William Butler Yeats]], [[Lady Gregory]], [[Lady Charlotte Guest]], [[Lady Llanover]], [[James Macpherson]], [[François-René de Chateaubriand|Chateaubriand]], [[Théodore Hersart de la Villemarqué]] and the many others influenced by them. This image coloured not only the English perception of their neighbours on the so-called "[[Celt belt|Celtic fringe]]" (compare the [[stage Irish]]man), but also [[Irish nationalism]] and its analogues in the other Celtic-speaking countries. Among the enduring products of this resurgence of interest in a romantic, pre-industrial, brooding, mystical Celticity are [[Gorsedd]]au, the revival of the [[Cornish language]],{{cite web|title=A brief history of the Cornish language|url=http://www.magakernow.org.uk/index.aspx?articleid=38590#Revival|publisher=Maga Kernow|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081225172227/http://www.magakernow.org.uk/index.aspx?articleid=38590#Revival|archivedate=25 December 2008|df=dmy-all}}{{Cite book|last=Ellis|first=Peter Berresford|authorlink=Peter Berresford Ellis|title=The Story of the Cornish Language|year=2005|publisher=Tor Mark Press|isbn=0-85025-371-3|pages=20–22}} and the revival of the [[Gaelic games]]. ==Contemporary Celtic identity== The ''modern Celtic'' groups' distinctiveness as ''national'', as opposed to regional, minorities has been periodically recognised by major British newspapers. For example, a ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' editorial in 1990 pointed to these differences, and said that they should be constitutionally recognised:
''Smaller minorities also have equally proud visions of themselves as irreducibly Welsh, Irish, Manx or Cornish. These identities are ''distinctly national'' in ways which ''proud people from [[Yorkshire]]'', much less proud people from [[Berkshire]] will never know. Any new constitutional settlement ''which ignores these factors'' will be built on uneven ground.''''[[The Guardian]]'', editorial, 8 May 1990
The Republic of Ireland, on surpassing [[UK|Britain]]'s GDP per capita in the 1990s for the first time, was given the moniker "[[Celtic tiger]]". Thanks in part to campaigning on the part of Cornish regionalists, [[Cornwall]] was able to obtain [[Objective One]] funding from the [[European Union]]. Scotland and Wales obtained agencies like the [[Welsh Development Agency]], and Scottish and Welsh Nationalists have recently supported the institution of the [[Scottish Parliament]] and [[National Assembly for Wales]]. More broadly, distinct identities in opposition to that of the metropolitan capitals have been forged and taken strong root.{{clarify|date=April 2012}} These latter evolutions have proceeded hand in hand with the growth of a [[pan-Celticism|pan-Celtic]] or inter-Celtic dimension, seen in many organisations and festivals operating across various Celtic countries. Celtic studies departments at many universities in Europe and beyond, have studied the various ancient and modern Celtic languages and associated history and folklore under one roof. Some of the most vibrant aspects of modern Celtic culture are music, song and festivals. Under the ''Music'', ''Festivals'' and ''Dance'' sections below, the richness of these aspects that have captured the world's attention are outlined.{{cite web|url=http://www.celticmp3s.com/things_celtic_music/Festivals_and_Pubs/|title=Things Celtic Music Directory : Festivals and Pubs|accessdate=9 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101225184959/http://www.celticmp3s.com/things_celtic_music/Festivals_and_Pubs/|archivedate=25 December 2010|df=dmy-all}} Sports such as [[Hurling]], [[Gaelic Football]] and [[Shinty]] are seen as being ''Celtic''. The USA has also taken part in discussions of modern Celticity. For example, [[Virginia]] [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[James H. Webb]], in his 2004 book ''[[Born Fighting|Born Fighting: How the Scots-Irish Shaped America]]'', controversially asserts that the early "pioneering" immigrants to North America were of [[Scotch-Irish American|Scots-Irish]] origins. He goes on to argue that their distinct ''Celtic traits'' (loyalty to kin, mistrust of governmental authority, and military readiness), in contrast to the ''[[Anglo-Saxons|Anglo-Saxon]]'' settlers, helped construct the modern ''American identity''. Irish Americans also played an important role in the shaping of 19th-century [[Irish republicanism]] through the [[Fenian]] movement and the development of view that the [[Irish Potato Famine (1845-1849)|Great Hunger]] was a British atrocity.{{cite web|last=Metress|first=Seamus|authorlink=Seamus Metress|title=The Great Starvation and British Imperialism in Ireland (University of Toledo)|url=http://homepage.ntlworld.com/chris.thorns/resources/Translations/iphunger.pdf|publisher=The Irish People|accessdate=12 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130718083224/http://homepage.ntlworld.com/chris.thorns/resources/Translations/iphunger.pdf|archivedate=18 July 2013|df=dmy-all}} ==Criticism of modern Celticism== {{primary sources|section|date=December 2016}} In 1996, Dr Ruth Megaw {{cite web |url=http://www.flinders.edu.au/artmuseum/collections/gifted-collections/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-02-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150204085136/http://www.flinders.edu.au/artmuseum/collections/gifted-collections/ |archivedate=4 February 2015 |df=dmy-all }} and Emeritus Professor Vincent Megaw {{cite web|url=http://www.flinders.edu.au/people/vincent.megaw|title=Vincent Megaw|website=Flinders.edu.au|accessdate=9 January 2018}} of Flinders University in the ''[[Antiquity (journal)|Antiquity]]'' article "Ancient Celts and modern ethnicity" examined ''ethnic identity'' particularly in relation to ''Celtic identity'' in arguing against critics seemingly motivated by an English nationalist agenda opposed to further integration with Europe who saw modern Celtic identity as a threat.{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Ancient+Celts+and+modern+ethnicity.-a018299489|title=Ancient Celts and modern ethnicity (full text)|last=Megaw|first=J. V. S & M. R.|accessdate=4 February 2015}}{{cite web|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=9434363|title=Ancient Celts and modern ethnicity (Antiquity web site stub)|last=Megaw|first=J. V. S & M. R.|accessdate=4 February 2015}} In 1998, Dr [[Simon James (archaeologist)|Simon James]] of the University of Leicester {{cite web|url=http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/archaeology/people/james|title=Professor Simon James — University of Leicester|first=|last=tk74|website=2.le.ac.uk|accessdate=9 January 2018}} in the ''Antiquity'' article "Celts, politics and motivation in archaeology" replied to Ruth and Vincent Megaw's article questioning the suitability of the term ''Celtic'' in the historic sense.{{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/Celts,+politics+and+motivation+in+archaeology.-a020632334|title=Celts, politics and motivation in archaeology.|accessdate=4 February 2015}} The core of his argument was that the Iron Age peoples of Britain should be considered not as generic Celts, but as a mosaic of different societies, each with their own traditions and histories. Later in 1998, this line of reasoning came under criticism, being labelled an intellectual extension of modern British cultural colonialism, as well as for simplifying the anthropological correlation between material culture and ethnicity. Ruth and Vincent Megaw in the Antiquity article "The Mechanism of (Celtic) Dreams?': A Partial Response to Our Critics." {{cite web|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/'The+mechanism+of+(Celtic)+dreams?':+a+partial+response+to+our...-a020912892|title='The mechanism of (Celtic) dreams?': a partial response to our critics. - Free Online Library|website=Thefreelibrary.com|accessdate=9 January 2018}} attacked 'Celt-sceptics' for being motivated by English nationalism or anxieties about the decline of British imperial power. Simon James, in 1998, wrote a response arguing that the rejection of a Celtic past was not 'nationalist' but partly due to archaeological evidence, and usually by a post-colonial and multi-cultural agenda with recognition that Britain has always been home to multiple identities.{{cite web|url=http://www.le.ac.uk/ar/stj/furthread.htm|title=Simon James's Ancient Celts Page – Further info|accessdate=24 December 2009}} Recently the Insular Celts have increasingly been seen as part of an Atlantic trading-networked culture speaking Celtic languages of the [[Atlantic Bronze Age]] and probably earlier.{{cite web|url=http://www.wales.ac.uk/Resources/Documents/Research/ODonnell.pdf|title=O'Donnell Lecture 2008 Appendix|website=Wales.ac.uk|accessdate=9 January 2018}} In 2003, Professor [[John Collis]]{{cite web|url=https://www.sheffield.ac.uk/archaeology/people/collis|title=Collis, J - Our Staff - Archaeology - The University of Sheffield|first=University of|last=Sheffield|website=Sheffield.ac.uk|accessdate=9 January 2018}} of the University of Sheffield wrote a book titled ''The Celts: Origins, Myths and Invention'', itself criticised in 2004 by Ruth and Vincent Megaw in ''Antiquity''.{{cite news|url=http://www.thefreelibrary.com/John+Collis.+The+Celts%3A+origins,+myths+and+inventions.-a0123120572|title=John Collis. The Celts: origins, myths and inventions|website=Thefreelibrary.com|accessdate=9 January 2018}} ==Celtic nations== [[File:Map of Celtic Nations-flag shades.svg|right|thumb|175px|The six Celtic nations]] {{Main|Celtic nations}} Six nations tend to be most associated with a modern Celtic identity, and are considered 'the Celtic nations'. :* [[Brittany]] :* [[Ireland]] :* [[Scotland]] :* [[Wales]] :* [[Isle of Man]] :* [[Cornwall]] It is these six nations that (alone) are considered Celtic by the [[Celtic League (political organisation)|Celtic League]] and the [[Celtic Congress]] amongst others.{{cite web|url=http://www.celticleague.net/ |title=The Celtic League |publisher=The Celtic League |year=2010|accessdate=20 February 2010 |work=Celtic League website }}{{cite web|url=http://www.ccheilteach.ie/cc-hist-mellis.html|title=Information on The International Celtic Congress Douglas, Isle of Man hosted by|publisher=[[Celtic Congress]]|language=Irish, English|year=2010|accessdate=20 February 2010|work=Celtic Congress website }} These organisations ascribe to a definition of Celticity based mainly upon language. In the aforementioned six regions, Celtic languages have survived and continue to be used to varying degrees in Ireland, Scotland, Wales, Isle of Man, Cornwall and Brittany.{{cite web|url=http://www.breizh.net/icdbl/saozg/Celtic_Languages.pdf |title=Visio-Map of Europe Celtic Europe.vsd |format=PDF |accessdate=31 October 2008}} There are also Celtic nomads: [[Irish Travellers]] called "Pavee" that speak a language called [[Shelta]] that is a creole of Irish Gaelic and other languages and [[Scottish Travellers#Indigenous Highland Travellers|Indigenous Highland Scottish Travellers]] called "Tinkers" who speak a language called [[Beurla Reagaird]] that is an [[acrolect]] of Scottish Gaelic.The last of the Tinsmiths: The Life of Willy MacPhee, by Shelia Douglas 2006Kirk, J. & Ó Baoill, D. ''Travellers and their Language'' (2002)[[Queen's University Belfast]] {{ISBN|0-85389-832-4}} A number of activists on behalf of other regions/nations have also sought recognition as modern Celts, reflecting the wide diffusion of ancient Celts across Europe. Of these, the most prominent are [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia / N. Portugal]], [[Asturias]] and [[Cantabria]]. A Celtic language did not survive in Galicia / Northern Portugal (together Gallaecia), Asturias nor Cantabria, and as such they fall outside of the [[Litmus test (politics)|litmus test]] used by the [[Celtic League (political organisation)|Celtic League]], and the [[Celtic Congress]]. Nevertheless, many organisations organised around Celticity consider that [[Galicia (Spain)|Galicia]] / Northern Portugal ([[Douro]], [[Minho Province|Minho]] and [[Trás-os-Montes (region)|Tras-os-Montes]]) and [[Asturias]] "can claim a Celtic cultural or historic heritage". These claims to Celticity are rooted in the long{{cite web|url=http://www4.uwm.edu/celtic/ekeltoi/volumes/vol6/6_11/gamito_6_11.pdf |title=The Celts in Portugal |format=PDF|website=4.uwm.edu |accessdate=16 January 2011}} historical existence of Celts in these regions and ethnic connections to other Atlantic Celtic peoples{{cite web|url=http://www4.uwm.edu/celtic/ekeltoi/volumes/vol6/6_5/alvarez_sanchis_6_5.pdf |title=Oppida and Celtic society in western Spain |format=PDF|website=4.uwm.edu |accessdate=31 October 2008}}{{cite web|url=http://www4.uwm.edu/celtic/ekeltoi/volumes/vol6/6_15/garcia_alonso_6_15.pdf |title=Briga Toponyms in the Iberian Peninsula |format=PDF|website=4.uwm.edu |accessdate=31 October 2008}} (see [[Celtiberians]], [[Celtici]] and [[Castro culture]]). In 2009, the Gallaic Revival Movement, sponsored by the Liga Celtiga Galaica (the Galician Celtic League), claimed to be reconstructing the Q-Celtic Gallaic language based on the ''Atebivota Dictionary'' and ''Old Celtic Dictionary'' compiled by Vincent F. Pintado.{{cite web|title=Old Celtic Dictionary|url=http://oldcelticdictionary.com/|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121104101146/http://www.oldcelticdictionary.com/|archivedate=4 November 2012|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://gallaic.com|title=Gallaic Revival|accessdate=11 May 2013|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130818010608/http://gallaic.com/#|archive-date=18 August 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://gallaicrevivalmovement.page.tl/|title=Gallaic Revival Movement|accessdate=11 May 2013}}{{cite web|url=http://gallaicrevivalmovement.spruz.com/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-05-11 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121002063828/http://gallaicrevivalmovement.spruz.com/ |archivedate=2 October 2012 |df=dmy-all }} Elements of Celtic music, dance, and folklore can be found within England (e.g. [[Yan Tan Tethera]], [[Well dressing]], [[Halloween]]), and the [[Cumbric language]] survived until the collapse of the [[Kingdom of Strathclyde]] in about 1018.Fischer, S. R. (2004) ''History of Language''. Reaktion Books, p. 118 England as a whole comprises many distinct regions, and some of these regions, such as [[Cumbria]], [[Lancashire]], and Western [[Yorkshire]] can claim more Celtic heritage than others.{{cite book|last=Moffat|first=Alistair|title=The Sea Kingdoms|year=2001|publisher=Harper Collins|location=London|isbn=0-00-653243-8|pages=20–22}} In 2009, it was claimed that revival of the [[Cumbric language]] was being attempted in the [[Cumberland]] area of England,{{cite journal |last1= Lewis|first1= Colin|last2= |first2= |year= 2009|title= Cumbrian Welsh – an update|journal=[[Carn]]|volume= 144 |page= 10|url=http://www.celticleague.net/wp-content/uploads/2010/02/CARN-144-October-2009.pdf|accessdate=8 December 2010}} however the idea that "Cumbric" was separate from Old [[Welsh language|Welsh]] has been criticised as stemming from the difficulty that many English historians have with accepting Old Welsh as the language once spoken all over England.{{cite book|last=Moffat|first=Alistair|title=The Sea Kingdoms|year=2001|publisher=Harper Collins|location=London|isbn=0-00-653243-8|page=20}} It was suggested by Colin Lewis in [[Carn]] magazine that revivalists in the [[north of England]] use [[Welsh language|Modern Welsh]] to enable use of Welsh's existing rich cultural basis rather than having to "reinvent the wheel" in much the same way as has been done successfully in [[Derbyshire]],{{cite web|title=Derby Welsh Learners Circle|url=http://derbywelshlearnerscircle.blogspot.com.au/|website=Derbywelshlearnerscircle.blogspot.com|accessdate=9 January 2018}} another area where elements of Celtic culture survive. Similarly, in France outside of Brittany, in the [[Auvergne (province)]] chants are sung around bonfires remembering a Celtic god.{{cite web|url=http://www.sacred-texts.com/neu/celt/rac/rac06.htm#fr_61|title=The Gods of Gaul and the Continental Celts|pages=Chapter 3|accessdate=7 May 2010}} There are also modern attempts to revive the polytheistic religion of [[Gauls]].{{cite web|title=Gaulish Polytheistic Reconstructionism|url=https://www.facebook.com/pages/Gaulish-Polytheistic-Reconstructionism/161315550632894?sk=info|website=Facebook.com|accessdate=9 January 2018}}{{cite web|title=Gaulish Reconstructionist Forum |url=http://gaulish-recon.livejournal.com/ |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130415125930/http://gaulish-recon.livejournal.com/ |archivedate=15 April 2013 |df=dmy-all }} ==Ancestry== {{Further|Scottish clan|Scottish Gaelic personal naming system|Irish names|Welsh surnames}} A profound interest in [[genealogy]] and [[family history]] is noted as a feature of the culture of the Celtic nations and regions and people with a Celtic heritage.{{cite book|last=Moffat|first=Alistair|title=The Sea Kingdoms|year=2001|publisher=Harper Collins|location=London|isbn=0-00-653243-8|pages=7,30–31,86,177–178}}{{cite web|url=http://www.family-ancestry.co.uk/history/celts/modern/ |title=Family Ancestry}} People in traditional Celtic areas can recite their genealogy back though the generations as history, moving rhythmically from one name to another using only Christian name as illustrated by lyrics of the [[Runrig]] song [[Sìol Ghoraidh]] "The Genealogy of Goraidh".{{cite web|title=Siol Ghoraidh - The {{sic|Gene|ology|hide=y}} Of Goraidh|url=http://www.jimwillsher.co.uk/Site/Runrig/Lyrics/Lyrics_Detail.php?AlbumID=9#SiolGhoraidh|accessdate=22 August 2012|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120717104012/http://www.jimwillsher.co.uk/Site/Runrig/Lyrics/Lyrics_Detail.php?AlbumID=9#SiolGhoraidh|archivedate=17 July 2012|df=dmy-all}} The disease, hereditary [[Haemochromatosis]], has by far its highest prevalence rate among people of Celtic ancestry.{{cite web|title=Haemochromatosis - The Celtic Disease|url=http://info.wirral.nhs.uk/document_uploads/CurrentVersion/Haemochromatosis%20-%20The%20Celtic%20Disease.pdf|accessdate=8 December 2014}} Another trait far more prevalent among people of Celtic ancestry is [[red hair]], with 46% of Irish and at least 36% of Highland Scots being carriers of red-head variants of the [[Melanocortin 1 receptor|MC1R gene]], possibly an adaptation to the cloudy weather of the areas where they live.{{cite web|last1=Moffat|first1=Alistair|title=Celts' red hair could be attributed to the cloudy weather|url=http://www.irishcentral.com/roots/could-irelands-cloudy-weather-be-the-reason-for-the-stereotypical-red-hair-178077221-237789031.html|accessdate=31 December 2014}}{{cite web|title=Red-Head|url=http://www.scotlandsdna.com/products/red-head|publisher=Scotlands DNA|accessdate=31 December 2014}} Although they are not usually considered a Celtic nation, the [[Faroe Islands]] has a population with a large Celtic heritage in genetic terms. Recent DNA analyses have revealed that Y chromosomes, tracing male descent, are 87% [[Scandinavia]]n.,{{cite journal |title=The origin of the isolated population of the Faroe Islands investigated using Y chromosomal markers |first=Tove H. |last=Jorgensen |first2=Henriette N. |last2=Buttenschön |first3=August G. |last3=Wang |first4=Thomas D. |last4=Als |first5=Anders D. |last5=Børglum |first6=Henrik |last6=Ewald |year=2004 |journal=Human Genetics |volume=115 |issue=1 |pages=19–28 |doi=10.1007/s00439-004-1117-7 |pmid=15083358}} whereas the [[mitochondrial DNA]], tracing female descent, is 84% Celtic.Wang, C. August. 2006. Ílegur og Føroya Søga. In: ''Frøði'' pp. 20–23 The same can be said about [[Icelanders]]. The founder population of [[Iceland]] came from Ireland, Scotland, and Scandinavia: studies of mitochondrial DNA and Y-chromosomes indicate that 62% of Icelanders' matrilineal ancestry derives from Scotland and Ireland (with most of the rest being from Scandinavia), while 75% of their patrilineal ancestry derives from Scandinavia (with most of the rest being from the Irish and British Isles). In addition, there are some areas of the accepted Celtic countries whose population are mostly not of Celtic heritage: for example, the [[Orkney Islands|Orkney]] and [[Shetland Islands]] in Scotland have a population of mostly Nordic descent.{{cite journal|last=Goodacre|first=S|author2=Helgason, A |author3=Nicholson, J |author4=Southam, L |author5=Ferguson, L |author6=Hickey, E |author7=Vega, E |author8=Stefánsson, K |author9=Ward, R |author10= Sykes, B |date=2005|title=Genetic evidence for a family-based Scandinavian settlement of Shetland and Orkney during the Viking periods|journal=Heredity|pmid=15815712|volume=95|issue=2|pages=129–135|doi=10.1038/sj.hdy.6800661}} ==Migration from Celtic countries== {{Main|Celtic diaspora (disambiguation)}} [[File:Banniel Keltia.svg|thumb|right|The Pan-Celtic flag]] A significant portion of the populations of the [[United States]], [[Canada]], [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]] is composed of people whose ancestors were from one of the "Celtic nations". This concerns the [[Irish diaspora]] most significantly (see also [[Irish American]]), but to a lesser extent also the [[Welsh diaspora]] and the [[Cornish diaspora]]. There are three areas outside Europe with communities of Celtic language speakers: *the province of [[Chubut Province|Chubut]] in [[Patagonia]] with Welsh-speaking [[Welsh Argentine]]s (known as ''[[Welsh settlement in Argentina|Y Wladfa]]'') * [[Cape Breton Island]] in Nova Scotia with [[Canadian Gaelic|Scottish Gaelic]]-speaking [[Scottish Canadians]] *southeast [[Newfoundland and Labrador|Newfoundland]] with Irish-speaking [[Irish Canadians]]. The most common mother-tongue amongst the [[Fathers of Confederation]] which saw the formation of Canada was [[Goidelic languages|Gaelic]].[http://www.pch.gc.ca/special/flag-drapeau/defi-challenge/reponses-answers_e.cfm Ministry of Canadian Heritage]. Gaelic most common mother-tongue among Fathers of Confederation. URL accessed 26/04/2006. There is a movement in [[Cape Breton Island|Cape Breton]] for a separate province in Canada, as espoused by the [[Cape Breton Labour Party]] and others. In some former British colonies, or particular regions within them, the term [[Anglo-Celtic]] has emerged as a descriptor of an ethnic grouping. In particular, [[Anglo-Celtic Australian]] is a term comprising about 80% of the population.[http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/7d12b0f6763c78caca257061001cc588/af5129cb50e07099ca2570eb0082e462!OpenDocument Australian Bureau of Statistics, 2003, "Population characteristics: Ancestry of Australia's population"] (from ''Australian Social Trends, 2003''). Retrieved 1 September 2006. ==Music== {{main|Celtic music}} {{Further|List of Celtic choirs}} [[Image:Gaiteiros em romaria galega.jpg|270px|Traditional Galician ''gaiteiros''|thumb]] The claim that distinctly Celtic styles of music exist was made during the nineteenth century, and was associated with the revival of folk traditions and pan-Celtic ideology. The Welsh anthem "[[Hen Wlad Fy Nhadau]]" was adopted as a pan-Celtic anthem.Loffler, Marion ''A Book of Mad Celts: John Wickens and the Celtic Congress of Caernarfon 1904'', Llandysul: Gomer Press, 2000, p. 38 Though there are links between Scots Gaelic and Irish Gaelic folk musics, very different musical traditions existed in Wales and Brittany. Nevertheless, Gaelic styles were adopted as typically Celtic even by Breton revivalists such as [[Paul Ladmirault]].Bempéchat, Paul-André, ''Allons enfants de quelle patrie? Breton nationalism and the Impressionist aesthetic'', (Center for European Studies working papers). [[Image:A Stivell 072707 Nuremberg 02.JPG|left|thumb|Breton harpist and Celtic music exponent [[Alan Stivell]] at Nuremberg, Germany, 2007]] Celticism came to be associated with the [[bagpipe]] and the [[harp]]. The harp is considered to be the national instrument of Wales and is used to accompany '''penillion''' singing (or '''[[cerdd dant]]''') where the harpist plays a melody and the singer sings in counterpoint to it.Brake, Julie & Jones, Christine (2000) ''Welsh: a complete course in understanding speaking and writing''. London: Hodder & Stoughton; p. 265 The [[roots revival]], applied to [[Celtic music]], has brought much inter-Celtic cross-fertilisation, as, for instance, the revival by Welsh musicians of the use of the mediaeval Welsh [[bagpipe]] under the influence of the Breton ''binioù'', Irish ''uillean'' pipes and famous Scottish pipes,{{cite web|url=http://www.ceolas.org/instruments/#pipes|title=Celtic Music Instruments|publisher=Ceolas.org |accessdate=22 April 2012}} or the Scots have revived the ''bodhran'' from Irish influence.{{cite web|url=http://www.ceolas.org/instruments/#bodhran |title=Celtic Music Instruments |publisher=Ceolas.org |accessdate=21 April 2012}} [[Charles le Goffic]] introduced the [[Great Highland Bagpipe|Scottish Highland pipes]] to Brittany. Unaccompanied or [[A cappella]]{{cite web|url=http://www.sydneyacappellafestival.com.au/content.cfm/performers/The+Australian+Gaelic+Singers|title=The Australian Gaelic Singers at the Sydney A Capella Festival|website=Sydneyacappellafestival.com.au|accessdate=9 May 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110601014417/http://www.sydneyacappellafestival.com.au/content.cfm/performers/The+Australian+Gaelic+Singers|archive-date=1 June 2011|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} styles of singing are performed across the modern Celtic world due to the folk music revival, popularity of [[List of Celtic choirs|Celtic choirs]], world music, scat singing{{cite web|last=Alarik|first=Scott|title=Irish Music and Scottish Music: What's the Difference, Really?|url=http://www.scottalarik.com/index.php?page=stories&family=&archives=show|website=Scottalarik.com.au|accessdate=9 January 2018}} and hip hop rapping in Celtic languages.{{cite web|url=http://www.danycownter.com/|title=Dan Y Cownter 3|language=Cymraeg, English|accessdate=9 May 2010}}{{cite web|url=http://www.welshmusicfoundation.com/|title=Welsh Music Foundation|language=Cymraeg, English|accessdate=9 May 2010}} Traditional rhythmic styles used to accompany dancing and now performed are [[Puirt a beul]] from Scotland, Ireland, and Cape Breton Island, Nova Scotia, [[Sean-nós song]] from Ireland and [[Kan ha diskan]] from Brittany. Other traditional unaccompanied styles sung currently are [[Waulking song]] and Psalm singing or [[Lining out]] both from Scotland.Robertson, Boyd & Taylor, Iain (1993) ''Gaelic: a complete course for beginners''. London: Hodder & Stoughton; p. 53 The emergence of [[folk-rock]] led to the creation of a popular music genre labelled [[Celtic music]] which "frequently involves the blending of traditional and modern forms, e.g. the Celtic-punk of [[The Pogues]], the ambient music of [[Enya]] ... the Celtic-rock of [[Runrig]], [[Rawlins Cross]] and [[Horslips]]."Shuker, Roy (2005) ''Popular Music: the key concepts'', Routledge; p. 38. Pan-Celtic music festivals were established, notably the [[Festival Interceltique de Lorient]] founded in 1971, which has occurred annually since. ==Festivals== [[File:Anoriant3.jpg|right|thumb|Pipers at the [[Festival Interceltique de Lorient]] in [[France]]|alt=Group of young men and women, wearing white shirts (some with black waistcoats) and black trousers, marching in a parade, in the sunshine. Each is playing a bagpipe. The bag is a claret colour. The entire picture is full of people. Those not taking part in the parade are watching the procession.]] {{Main|List of Celtic festivals}} {{See also|Céilidh|Eisteddfod|Mod (Scotland)|Fleadh Cheoil|Fleadh|Fest Noz|Troyl}} {{Further|Clootie well|Celtic Reconstructionist Paganism}} The Scottish [[Mod (Scotland)|Mod]] and Irish [[Fleadh Cheoil]] (and [[Gaels|Gaelic]] [[Céilidh]]) are seen as an equivalent to the Breton [[Fest Noz]], Cornish [[Troyl]]{{cite book|last=Melhuish|first=Martin|title=Celtic Tides: Traditional Music in a New Age|year=1998|publisher=Quarry Press Inc.|location=Ontario, Canada|isbn=1-55082-205-5|page=169}} and Welsh [[Eisteddfod]].{{cite web|url=http://www.analekta.com/media/analekta/analekta/file/1235402868_file.pdf|title=Wales – Land of Song|year=2008|accessdate=12 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716021827/http://www.analekta.com/media/analekta/analekta/file/1235402868_file.pdf|archivedate=16 July 2011|df=dmy-all}}{{cite web|url=http://www.druidcircle.org/library/index.php?title=Celtic_Music|title=Celtic Music|accessdate=12 May 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100514061031/http://www.druidcircle.org/library/index.php?title=Celtic_Music|archivedate=14 May 2010|df=dmy-all}}Robertson, Boyd and Taylor, Iain ''Gaelic – A Complete Course for Beginners''; p. 63 The [[Celtic Media Festival]] is an annual 3 day event that promotes the languages and cultures of the Celtic Nations and Regions in media. This festival takes place in a different Celtic nation every year and has been running since 1980. The birthdays of the most important Celtic Saints of [[Celtic Christianity]] for each [[Celtic nation]] have become the focus for festivals, feasts and marches: Ireland – [[Saint Patrick's Day]],{{cite web|title=St Patrick's Day Parades and Events Worldwide|url=http://www.st-patricks-day.com/st_patricks_day_parades_home.asp|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100525173457/http://www.st-patricks-day.com/st_patricks_day_parades_home.asp|archivedate=25 May 2010|df=dmy-all}} Wales – [[Saint David's Day]],{{cite web|title=The National St David's Day Parade|url=http://www.stdavidsday.org/|website=Stdavidsday.org|accessdate=9 January 2018}} Scotland – [[Saint Andrew's Day]],{{cite web|title=St Andrew's Day: Scotland and around the world|url=http://www.scotland.org/standrewsday/|website=Scotland.org|accessdate=9 January 2018}} Cornwall – [[Saint Piran's Day]],{{cite web|title=St Piran's Tide|url=http://www.an-daras.com/cutoms/cu_stpirans_events.htm|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126105453/http://www.an-daras.com/cutoms/cu_stpirans_events.htm|archivedate=26 January 2012|df=dmy-all}} Isle of Man – St [[Maughold]]'s Feast Day{{cite web|title=St Maughold's Feast Day |url=http://www.isle-of-man.com/manxnotebook/parishes/md/stmaugh.htm}} and Brittany – Fete de la [[Ivo of Kermartin|St-Yves]] and Grand Pardon of [[Sainte-Anne-d'Auray]] Pilgrimage.{{cite web|title=Saint Yves|url=http://www.catholic-saints.info/patron-saints/saint-yves.htm|accessdate=2 March 2012}}{{cite web|last=Bretons de Sydney|title=Fete de la St -Yves|url=http://home.exetel.com.au/jpleloch/BretonsSydney.html|website=Home.exetel.com.au|accessdate=2 March 2012}}{{cite web|title=Grand Pardon de sainte Anne d'Auray|url=http://sainte-anne-auray.net/spip.php?article72|website=Sainte-anne-auray.net|accessdate=9 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150511141304/http://sainte-anne-auray.net/spip.php?article72|archive-date=11 May 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} [[Image:Clouties near madron well.jpg|thumb|width=200px|right|Cloths tied to a tree near Madron Well in Cornwall]] Attitudes and customs associated with the routine of the year's work, religious beliefs and practices survived the coming of Christianity in the conservative rural areas of much of the Celtic countries.{{cite book|last=Kruta|first=Venceslas|title=The Celts|year=1991|publisher=Thames and Hudson|page=671}} All over these lands there were sacred places which had earned their status in pre-Christian times and which had only been gingerly adopted by the Christian church and given a garnish of Christian names or dedications, hills, stones, and especially wells which can still be seen festooned with rags in observance of an old ritual. Certain days in the year were marked as festivals, and time was counted forward and backwards from them without reference to the ordinary calendar. In her fine study of the festival of the beginning of harvest, in Irish ''[[Lughnasa]]'', [[Máire MacNeill]] has demonstrated the continuity between the myth known from the early Middle Ages and the customs which survive to our own day. Lughnasa, called [[Calan Awst]] in Welsh, is a summer feast and was dedicated to the god [[Lugh|Lug]].{{cite book|last=Cremin|first=Aedeen|title=The Celts in Europe|year=1992|publisher=Sydney Series in Celtic Studies 2, Centre for Celtic Studies, University of Sydney|location=Sydney, Australia|isbn=0-86758-624-9|pages=83–84,112}}{{cite web|last=Jones|first=Mary|title=Jones' Celtic Encyclopedia – Lughnassadh|url=http://www.maryjones.us/jce/lughnassadh.html|accessdate=11 December 2011}} Of great interest is the use in the [[Coligny calendar]] of the word ''[[Samhain|Saman]]'', a word that is still in use in Gaelic refer to [[Hallowe'en]] (evening of the saints), an important day and night and feast among the Celts (in Welsh it is called [[Calan Gaeaf]]).{{cite web|last=Jones|first=Mary|title=Jones' Celtic Encyclopedia – Samhain|url=http://www.maryjones.us/jce/samhain.html|accessdate=11 December 2011}} In Gaelic folklore, it was considered a particularly dangerous time, when magical spirits wandered through the land, particularly at nightfall. The other important feast days that also continued to be celebrated under Christian guise, but often with a pagan spirit were [[Imbolc]] ([[Gŵyl Fair y Canhwyllau]] in Welsh),{{cite web|last=Jones|first=Mary|title=Jones' Celtic Encyclopedia – Imbolc|url=http://www.maryjones.us/jce/imbolc.html|accessdate=11 December 2011}} the start of lambing, now the feast day of St Brigit and [[Beltane]],{{cite web|last=Jones|first=Mary|title=Jones' Celtic Encyclopedia – Beltane|url=http://www.maryjones.us/jce/beltane.html|accessdate=11 December 2011}} the spring feast, now May Day ([[Calan Mai]] in Welsh).{{cite book|last=Sharp|first=Mark|title=Holy Places of Celtic Britain|year=1997|publisher=Blandford|location=London|isbn=0-7137-2642-3|page=136}}{{cite book|last=Ross|first=Anne|title=Everyday Life of the Pagan Celts|year=1972|publisher=Carousel Books|isbn=0-552-54021-8|pages=197–201}} In their pilgrimages the people combined the celebration of a holy place and a holy day.{{cite book|last=Kruta|first=Venceslas|title=The Celts|year=1991|publisher=Thames and Hudson|page=672}} Pilgrimages are still an important feature of country life, particularly in Ireland, Brittany and Galicia. The most impressive pilgrimages include [[Croagh Patrick]] on the west coast of Ireland on the last Sunday in July (the beginning of harvest) and [[Santiago de Compostela]] in Galicia. The inspiration for famous Celtic singer and harpist [[Loreena McKennitt]]'s million-selling CD ''The Mask and the Mirror'' came in part from a visit to Galicia and in particular Santiago de Compostela.{{cite book|last=Melhuish|first=Martin|title=Celtic Tides: Traditional Music in a New Age|year=1998|publisher=Quarry Press Inc.|location=Ontario, Canada|isbn=1-55082-205-5|page=174}} Some of her songs are about Celtic feast days such as ''All Souls Night'' about [[Samhain]] on ''[[The Visit (Loreena McKennitt album)|The Visit]]'' CD which featured in the erotic thriller film [[Jade (film)|Jade]] starring [[David Caruso]] and "Huron [[Beltane]] Fire Dance" on the [[Parallel Dreams]] CD.CD liner notes{{cite web|title=Explore the Music: Loreena McKennitt|url=http://www.quinlanroad.com/explorethemusic/index.asp|publisher=Quinlan Road|accessdate=14 January 2012}} ==Dance== [[Image:Maypole Dancing on Village Green - geograph.org.uk - 1628839.jpg|thumb|300px|left|Children dancing around a [[maypole]] as part of a [[May Day]] celebration in Welwyn, England]] [[Image:Girls performing Irish step dancing in a St. Patrick's Day Parade in Fort Collins, Colorado.jpg|thumb|200px|right|[[Irish stepdance]]: Irish dancers at [[St. Patrick's Day]] parade in [[Fort Collins, Colorado]]]] To signal the coming of summer and the return of real warmth, on [[Beltane]] (''[[Belenus|Bel's Fire]]''), the May Day festival time, dances such as the [['Obby 'Oss]] dance festival at [[Padstow]] in Cornwall are held with the [[maypole#Britain and Ireland|maypole]] as its focus point.{{cite book|last=Moffat|first=Alistair|title=The Sea Kingdoms|year=2001|publisher=Harper Collins|location=London|isbn=0-00-653243-8|pages=104–106}}{{cite book|last=Melhuish|first=Martin|title=Celtic Tides: Traditional Music in a New Age|year=1998|publisher=Quarry Press Inc.|location=Ontario, Canada|isbn=1-55082-205-5|pages=168–169}} The celebrations are tied to the promotion of fertility and a fruitful growing season with the 'Obby 'Oss dancing to the music through streets decked out in flowers, and sycamore, ash and maple boughs. Shortly after on 8 May, the ancient rites of Spring are celebrated with the [[Furry Dance]] procession to an ancient tune made famous in the song "[[The Floral Dance]]" through the streets of nearby [[Helston]] together with the [[mystery play]] [[Hal an Tow]].{{cite book|last=Melhuish|first=Martin|title=Celtic Tides: Traditional Music in a New Age|year=1998|publisher=Quarry Press Inc.|location=Ontario, Canada|isbn=1-55082-205-5|page=168}} Fertility festivals like this used to be celebrated all over Britain.{{cite book|last=Moffat|first=Alistair|title=The Sea Kingdoms|year=2001|publisher=Harper Collins|location=London|isbn=0-00-653243-8|pages=15–17}} In the early 1980s seven-time world champion [[Irish stepdance|step-dancer]], [[Michael Flatley]] toured the world with [[The Chieftains]] and performed five solo dances (including a triple spin) at [[Carnegie Hall]], New York, in a defining moment that led more than a decade later to a show at the [[Eurovision Song Contest]] in Dublin that soon developed into the Irish dance extravaganza the world came to know as [[Riverdance]]{{cite book|last=Melhuish|first=Martin|title=Celtic Tides: Traditional Music in a New Age|year=1998|publisher=Quarry Press Inc.|location=Ontario, Canada|isbn=1-55082-205-5|pages=31–32}}{{cite web|title=Gaelforce Dance – The Irish Dance Spectacular|url=http://www.gaelforce-dance.com/|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120220055126/http://www.gaelforce-dance.com/|archivedate=20 February 2012|df=dmy-all}} [[Jean Butler]], one of the original leads, also worked with The Chieftains. Flatley later put up his own show, [[Lord of the Dance (musical)|Lord of the Dance]]. The spectacular success of both shows can certainly take the credit for the revitalised [[Celtomania]] of the last half of the 1990s. ==Arts and crafts== [[File:"Possible Productions knotwork" by Steve Ball.png|right|thumb|alt=Modern Celtic-inspired design involving a circle surrounding a triangle; between them are undulating and crossing patterns. The background is crimson.|Inspired by [[George Bain (artist)|Bain]]{{'s}} monograph on [[Celtic knot]]s, Steve Ball's knotwork appears on the cover of the ''[[Discipline (King Crimson album)|Discipline]]'' album of [[King Crimson#King Crimson.2C line-up 4 .281981.E2.80.931984.29|King Crimson]].]] Revival of [[Celtic art]] has been seen in the [[Celtic knot|Celtic jewellery]] that revived ancient traditions based on the museum pieces that archaeologists had recovered.{{cite book|last1=Walker, Kelly, MacArthur, Breen|first1=W.,T.,E.M.,A|title=The Modern History of Celtic Jewellery 1840-1980|date=9 May 2013|publisher=Walker Metalsmiths|isbn=0615805299|pages=1–76|url=http://www.bookdepository.com/book/9780615805290?redirected=true&v=A75X6&selectCurrency=AUD&gclid=Cj0KEQiA2o6lBRCn_b7yppe98rQBEiQAMpnYnZ9yUS91KxaH5sluvtA74FDS7PcMJxCo1ogI_Y0BZcwaAp2Y8P8HAQ|accessdate=1 January 2015}} An example is the [[Claddagh ring]] produced in [[Galway]] since at least 1700, but popularised in the 1840s.Jack Mulveen. (1994.) "Galway Goldsmiths, Their Marks and Ware", ''Journal of the [[Galway Archaeological and Historical Society]]'', [https://www.jstor.org/stable/25535635 46:43–64]. Textile craft industries based on Celtic fisher designs such as [[Aran jumper]]s were developed in the early 1900s by enterprising island women to earn income.{{cite book|last1=Starmore|first1=Alice|title=Aran Knitting|date=2010|publisher=Dover Publications Inc.|location=New York|pages=10–13|isbn=978 0 486 47842 5}} Following the authoritative publications on Celtic Art of the [[Hallstatt culture|Hallstatt]] and [[La Tene culture|La Tene]] periods by Joseph Déchelette (1908-1914) and [[Paul Jacobsthal]] (1944),{{cite book|last1=Déchelette,|first1=Joseph|title=Manuel d'archéologie préhistorique, celtique et gallo-romaine|date=1914|publisher=Librairie Alphonse Picard et fils|location=Paris|url=https://archive.org/details/manueldarcholog02grengoog|accessdate=4 February 2015}}{{cite book|last1=Jacobsthal|first1=Paul|title=Early Celtic Art|date=1944|publisher=Clarendon Press|location=Oxford|url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=8430322&fileId=S0075435800076231}} Scottish artist [[George Bain (artist)|George Bain]] popularized the revival of Celtic Art with his bestselling book ''Celtic Art: The Methods of Construction'' first published in 1951.{{cite book|last1=Bain|first1=George|title=Celtic Art: The Methods of Construction|date=1951|publisher=Constable and Company Ltd|location=London|isbn=0094618305|url=http://g.imagination.eu.org/books/celtic%20art/Bain,%20George%20-%20Celtic%20Art,%20The%20Methods%20of%20Construction.pdf|accessdate=4 February 2015|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150204054042/http://g.imagination.eu.org/books/celtic%20art/Bain,%20George%20-%20Celtic%20Art,%20The%20Methods%20of%20Construction.pdf|archive-date=4 February 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}{{cite book|last1=Ellis|first1=Peter Beresford|title=Celtic Dawn|date=2002|publisher=Y Lolfa|location=Ceredigion|isbn=0862436435|page=156|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zN1MfPvZS_EC&pg=PA156&lpg=PA156&dq=jim+fitzpatrick+celtic+art&source=bl&ots=_85k-eYUsc&sig=2eKEZGib221In5R6PmOVCEuozQQ&hl=en&sa=X&ei=Uv_PVPz7JMbCmwWzvIDABg&ved=0CCQQ6AEwAjge#v=onepage&q=jim%20fitzpatrick%20celtic%20art&f=false|accessdate=4 February 2015}} Irish artist and writer [[Jim Fitzpatrick (artist)|Jim Fitzpatrick]] started to hold popular attention from the mid-1970s adopting [[Irish mythology]] in comic strip form in his series of books and posters ''Nuada of the Silver Arm''.{{cite book|last1=Fitzpatrick|first1=Jim|title=The Book of Conquests|date=1978|publisher=Paper Tiger|isbn=0905895134}}{{cite web|last1=Fitzpatrick|first1=Jim|title=Jim Fitzpatrick Gallery|url=http://www.jimfitzpatrick.com/myhome/welcome-to-the-art-of-jim-fitzpatrick/|website=Jimfitzpatrick.com|accessdate=9 January 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150509060211/http://www.jimfitzpatrick.com/myhome/welcome-to-the-art-of-jim-fitzpatrick/|archive-date=9 May 2015|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} From the 1980s, public fascination with Celtic Art spawned a small industry in Celtic art books and reinterpretations of ancient Celtic art works, such as the works of Welsh artist Courtney Davies.{{cite web|last1=Davies|first1=Courtney|title=The Art of Courtney Davies.|url=http://www.courtneydavisart.com/|website=Courtneydavisart.com|accessdate=9 January 2018}} ==Literature and mythology== {{main|Celtic literature|Celtic mythology}} Similarly, here has been a rebirth of interest in fantasy fiction based on Celtic themes inspired by history and [[Celtic mythology|the vast body of Celtic myths and legends]]. ==See also== *[[Anglo-Celtic]] *[[Celtic Congress]] *[[Celtic League (political organisation)|Celtic League]] *[[Celtic Neopaganism]] *[[Celtic Revival]] *[[Pan-Celticism]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== * {{Cite book|title=Celtic Culture: A Historical Encyclopedia |author=John Koch |year=2006 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |isbn=1-85109-440-7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=f899xH_quaMC&printsec=frontcover&dq=Celtic+Culture:+A+Historical+Encyclopedia#v=onepage&q&f=false}} * {{Cite book|title=The Sea Kingdoms: The History of Celtic Britain and Ireland |author=Alistair Moffat |year=2001 |publisher=HarperCollins |isbn=0-00-257216-8 |url=https://www.amazon.co.uk/Sea-Kingdoms-History-Britain-Ireland/dp/0002572168 }} * {{cite news|url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_hb3284/is_n267_v70/ai_n28668313/?tag=content;col1|title=Ancient Celts and modern ethnicity |last=Megaw|first=J. V. S & M. R.|year=1996 | accessdate=11 April 2010 | work=Antiquity}} * {{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3B0LFhbmkocC&pg=PR6 |title=Celtoscepticism. A convenient excuse for ignoring non-archaeological evidence? |year=2004 |last=Karl|first=Raimund|accessdate=12 May 2010}} * [[Peter Berresford Ellis|Ellis, P. B.]] (1992) "Introduction". ''Dictionary of [[Celtic Mythology]]''. Oxford University Press * [[Norman Davies|Davies, Norman]] (1999) ''The Isles: a history''. Oxford University Press * [[Michael Dietler|Dietler, Michael]] (2006) " Celticism, Celtitude, and Celticity: the consumption of the past in the age of globalization". ''Celtes et Gaulois dans l’histoire, l’historiographie et l’idéologie moderne''. Bibracte, Centre Archéologique Européen. * ''Les Écossais du Québec'' (1999). Montréal: Conseil québécois du Chardon. ''N.B''.: This is primarily a descriptive cultural and commercial directory of the Scottish community of Québec. * O'Driscoll, Robert (ed.) (1981) ''The Celtic Consciousness''. George Braziller, Inc, New York City. * Patrick Ryan, 'Celticity and storyteller identity: the use and misuse of ethnicity to develop a storyteller's sense of self', ''Folklore'' 2006. ==External links== *[http://www7.nationalgeographic.com/ngm/0603/sights_n_sounds/index.html The Celtic Realm] *[http://www.celticcountries.com/ CelticCountries.com – Monthly magazine on current affairs in the Celtic nations] *{{cite web|url= http://www7.nationalgeographic.com/ngm/0603/feature3/images/mp_download.3.pdf |title=National Geographic Map: The Celtic Realm }} {{small|(306 KB)}} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080608085721/http://www.maryjones.us/jce/jce_index.html Jones' Celtic Encyclopedia] ;Music *[http://www.danycownter.com/ Dan Y Cownter 3] – Welsh Music Foundation artists (Cymraeg, English) *[http://www.celticlyricscorner.net/cliar/puirt1.htm Puirt a beul in Cliar] – Celtic Lyrics Corner (Gàidhlig, English) *[http://www.kesson.com/ KESSON The Cornish Musician's Collaborative] (Kernewek, English) {{Celts}} {{Celtic nations}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2012}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Celts (Modern)}} [[Category:Celtic Revival| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Europe by region]] [[Category:Cultural regions|Celtic]] [[Category:Ethnicity in politics]] [[Category:National identities]] [[sv:De keltiska nationerna]]
#REDIRECT [[Adavere]] [[Category:Geographical centres|Estonia]]

The '''geology of [[Zambia]]''' formed beginning in the [[Proterozoic]] eon of the [[Precambrian]]. The igneous and metamorphic basement rocks tend to be highly-metamorphosed and may have formed earlier in the [[Archean]], but heat and pressure has destroyed evidence of earlier conditions. Major sedimentary and metamorphic groups formed in the mid-Proterozoic, followed by a series of glaciations in the [[Neoproterozoic]] and much of the [[Paleozoic]] which deposited glacial [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]] as well as other sediments to form the [[Katanga Supergroup]] and rift-related [[Karoo Supergroup]]. Basalt eruptions blanketed the Karoo Supergroup in the [[Mesozoic]] and Zambia shifted to coal and sandstone formation. Geologically recent windblown sands from the [[Kalahari Desert]] and alluvial deposits near rivers play an important role in the modern surficial geology of Zambia. The country has extensive natural resources, particularly copper, but also cobalt, emeralds, other gemstones, uranium and coal.
==Stratigraphy & Geologic History== The oldest rocks in Zambia are part of the crystalline [[Precambrian]] basement complex, outcropping in the east and as the structurally complex [[Lufubu System]] in the [[Copperbelt]]. The [[granite]], [[gneiss]], [[migmatite]], [[schist]], [[amphibolite]], [[charnockite]], [[granulite]], [[khondalite]], [[phyllite]], [[limestone]] and metaquartzite basement rocks date to the [[Paleoproterozoic]]. Due to extensive metamorphism and deformation, they were altered from older rocks, obscuring the geologic history of the region. Additionally, the basement rocks are intruded by other granites, [[syenite]], [[dolerite]], [[gabbro]], [[rhyolite]], [[andesite]], metavolcanic and ultrabasic rocks. Although primarily exposed in the north and east, dome outcrops of basement rock exist at other locations in the country.
A one billion year [[Proterozoic]] [[unconformity]] separates the basement rock from the [[conglomerate (geology)|conglomerate]], [[quartzite]], schists, iron-rich sandstones and mudstones of the [[Muva Supergroup]].The supergroup is intruded by [[carbonatite]], dolerite, granite, granite [[porphyry (geology)|porphyry]], [[lamprophyre]], [[norite]], [[pegmatite]] and other igneous rock types. A rhyolite porphyritic belt, formed at the same time as the Muva Supergroup extends along the eastern bank of the [[Luapula River]], between [[Lake Tanganyika]] and [[Lake Mweru]]. <ref>{{cite book |author=Schluter, Thomas |year=2006|title=Geological Atlas of Africa|publisher=Springer|p=270}}</ref>
In the [[Neoproterozoic]], the [[Katanga Supergroup]] deposited conglomerate, shale, [[argillite]], quartzite, [[arkose]], [[greywacke]], [[dolomite]] and aeolian sandstones unconformably atop both the Muva Supergroup and Precambrian basement rocks. {{sfn|Schluter|2014|p=271}}
===Paleozoic=== The deposition of the Katanga Supergroup continued into the [[Cambrian]], in parallel with the rapid expansion of multi-cellular life. Geologists divide the supergroup into the [[Roan Group]], [[Mwasha Group]] and [[Kundelungu Group]] in the Copperbelt, and simply into upper and lower units elsewhere. The Roan Group hosts much of the copper in the Copperbelt as [[chalcopyrite]], [[chalcocite]], [[bornite]], [[malachite]] and [[azurite]], in [[shale]], sandstone, dolomite and quartzite associated with the margins of the Kafue [[syncline]].
The Kundelungu Group dolomites, limestones and carbonaceous shales unconformably overly the Mwasha Group [[shale]], argillite and interbedded quartzites. The lower unit of the Kundelungu Group is a conglomerate formed from glacial sediments, potentially related to the [[Hirnantian]] glaciation in the [[Ordovician]], as Zambia, within the [[supercontinent]] [[Gondwana]] drifted close to the South Pole.
In the mid-Paleozoic, a large rift valley formed across southern Gondwana, spanning much of what is now southern Africa and southern South America. The [[Karoo Supergroup]], the most widespread stratigraphic unit in southern Africa deposited in the rift. In Zambia, the Karoo Supergroup is represented by outcrops in major rift block valleys, in the east and south, such as the Luangwa, Lukusashi, Lunsemfwa, Rufunsa and mid-Zambezi rivers. Because glaciations continued throughout much of the Paleozoic, into the [[Permian]], in Gondwana, the bottom sequence of Karoo Supergroup rocks is a [[tillite]] that appears to be glacially produced. Ascending units includes sandstones and the Gwembe Coal Formation, mudstones and additional sandstones. {{sfn|Schluter|2014|p=271}}
===Mesozoic-Cenozoic (251 million years ago-present)=== Deposition of the Karoo Supergroup continued into the [[Mesozoic]], with the sequence capped by basalt lava flows from the [[Jurassic]]. Today, the basalt is exposed on the walls of Batoka Gorge, below [[Victoria Falls]].
The Karoo Supergroup is overlain by [[Late Jurassic]] and [[Cretaceous]] sandstones and mudstone, and intruded by [[carbonatite]] and [[kimberlite]].
During the past 66 million years of the [[Cenozoic]], the [[Kalahari Desert]] underwent a major expansion during a long lasting dry period. In the [[Neogene]] through the [[Pleistocene]], this climate change deposited moderately consolidated sandstones and windblown sands as the [[Kalahari Group]] in the Western Province and other parts of northwest, south and central Zambia. Pleistocene and [[Holocene]] alluvial deposits line the major rivers, as well as the Bangweulu Swamps and Kafue Flats. {{sfn|Schluter|2014|p=271}}
==Hydrogeology== [[Quaternary]] alluvial aquifers and the 20 to 40 meter unconsolidated sands of the Kalahari Group, in western and northeastern Zambia are recharged by rainwater, although the Kalahari Group has some issues with brackish water.
Several units of the [[Katanga Supergroup]] form consolidated, fracture flow aquifers in the Roan dolomite, Kundelungu limestone, Roan quartzites and Muva Supergroup. Brackish water is held in the unconfined, high porosity Karoo Group sandstones. By contrast, Karoo basalts, interbedded with sandstones and recharged through fractures tend to yield high quality water.
Large parts of the country are underlain by granite and gabbro crystalline basement rock. These rocks are generally impermeable, but store water in 10 to 15 meter thick weathered [[regolith]] and fractures.<ref>{{cite article |title=Hydrogeology of Zambia|publisher=British Geological Survey|url=http://earthwise.bgs.ac.uk/index.php/Hydrogeology_of_Zambia#Hydrogeology}}</ref>
==Natural resource geology== Zambia has extensive natural resources, most famously the copper ore of the [[Roan Group]], which gave rise to the [[Copperbelt]] region. Until the rapid decline in copper prices in the mid-1970s, copper mining formed the backbone of the [[economy of Zambia]]. Demand has picked up for copper, along with secondary production of cobalt. The country has deposits of iron, zinc, lead and tin, as well as small scale gemstone mining from basement rock. The Ndola area has emerald, aquamarine, garnet and talc.
Lower Karoo rocks host coal, while Upper Karoo rocks contain uranium. {{sfn|Schluter|2014|p=272}}
==References== {{portal|Geology|Zambia|Prehistory of Africa}} {{reflist}} {{Clear}} {{Africa topic|Geology of}}

Disambiguating links to [[Talus]] (link changed to [[Scree]]) using [[User:Certes/DisamAssist|DisamAssist]].
revision.text:
[[File:Habachtal Talschluss 2016.jpg|thumb|The head of the ''Habachtal'' valley in the [[High Tauern]] in [[Austria]]]] The '''head of the valley''' or, less commonly, the '''valley head''', refers to the uppermost part of a [[valley]].<ref name=Leser>Leser (2005), p. 935.</ref>
== Description == The head of a valley may take widely differing forms;<ref name=Leser/> for example, in [[highland]] regions the valley often ends in a broad, evenly sloping hollow. The higher the head of the valley, the more likely it is to resemble the geomorphological shape of a [[cirque]]. In [[glacial valley]]s or [[trough valley]]s, it may be referred to as the [[trough head]] or [[trough end]].<ref>Leser (2005), p. 978.</ref>
In mountains with predominantly [[crystalline rock]] the heads of the valleys are generally very wet, sometimes [[bog]]gy and often support lush [[alpine meadow]]s, whilst those made of [[limestone]] are usually dry and covered in [[Scree|talus]] or [[gravel]]. Where there has been [[ice age]] glaciation, the valley bottoms are modified by [[moraine]]s and mountain lakes are common.
== See also == * [[Structural basin]] * [[U-shaped valley|U-shaped or trough valley]] * [[Landform]] * [[Valley step]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
== Bibliography == * Leser, Hartmut, ed. (2005). ''Wörterbuch Allgemeine Geographie'', 13th ed., dtv, Munich, {{ISBN|978-3-423-03422-7}}.
